EAPD-BIO.0026-12; E-302-2011/-US-01; PORTER; PATENT LEGAL SERVICES

MOTIVATION THE DESIGN AND OPERATION OF AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS REQUIRES THE CONSIDERATION OF MULTIPLE OPERATING CHARACTERISTICS SUCH AS ENVIRONMENT, SAFETY, CAPACITY, ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE. THESE CHARACTERISTICS CAN BE USED TO DEFINE DIMENSIONS OF A TRADE SPACE FROM WHICH TRADE-OFFS BETWEEN THEM CAN BE EXPLORED IN SUPPORT OF OPERATIONAL, SYSTEM IMPROVEMENT AND POLICY DECISIONS. THE TRADE SPACE WHICH MUST BE CONSIDERED HAS EVOLVED AND BECOME SIGNIFICANTLY MORE COMPLEX AS THE AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM HAS MATURED AND AS THE SOCIETAL EXPECTATIONS FOR THE SYSTEM HAVE INCREASED. INITIALLY, THERE WAS OFTEN A SINGLE DOMINANT OBJECTIVE TO SYSTEM ENHANCEMENTS, SUCH AS IMPROVING SAFETY. AS THE SYSTEM BECAME MORE CONGESTED, NEW DRIVERS SUCH AS CAPACITY AND EFFICIENCY EMERGED. MORE RECENTLY, ENVIRONMENTAL CONSIDERATIONS ARE INCREASING AND MUST BE BALANCED AGAINST THE OTHER TRADITIONAL METRICS IN OPTIMIZING HOW THE SYSTEM OPERATES, AS WELL AS DEFINING THE REQUIREMENTS FOR SYSTEM EVOLUTION AND ENHANCEMENT SUCH AS NEXTGEN. IN ADDITION TO THE MACRO-LEVEL TRADEOFFS BETWEEN SYSTEM PERFORMANCE CATEGORIES SUCH AS ENVIRONMENT, SAFETY, CAPACITY AND ECONOMICS, THERE ARE ALSO TRADE-OFFS OCCURRING WITHIN A GIVEN SYSTEM PERFORMANCE DIMENSION, SUCH AS BETWEEN THE DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT AREAS OF NOISE, AIR QUALITY AND CLIMATE. THIS RESULTS IN A HIGHLY DIMENSIONAL TRADE HYPERSPACE WHICH NEEDS TO BE CONSIDERED TO BETTER OPTIMIZE THE SYSTEM PERFORMANCE. THE TRADITIONAL TRADE ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES, WHICH HAVE BEEN EMPLOYED IN AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT SUCH AS SIMPLE COSTBENEFIT ANALYSES, DO NOT SIMULTANEOUSLY CONSIDER THESE MULTIPLE DIMENSIONS. THE DIFFERENT VALUE STRUCTURES DIFFERENT STAKEHOLDERS PLACE ON ATTRIBUTES OF SYSTEM PERFORMANCE MAKE IT EVEN MORE DIFFICULT TO HAVE A GLOBAL DEFINITION OF OPTIMALITY ON WHICH TO BASE TRADE ANALYSES. OBJECTIVES THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO DEVELOP METHODOLOGIES FOR MULTI-DIMENSIONAL TRADE ANALYSIS AND OPTIMIZATION OF AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM PERFORMANCE, INCLUDING ENVIRONMENTAL CONSIDERATIONS. IN ADDITION, NEW APPROACHES FOR DEFINING UTILITY WILL BE EXPLORED TO ADDRESS ISSUES OF NONHOMOGENOUS METRICS OF PERFORMANCE AND DYNAMIC STAKEHOLDER DEPENDANT VALUE STRUCTURES, WHICH ARISE IN CONSIDERING THE BALANCE BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL AND OTHER SYSTEM PERFORMANCE. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO 1. DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR HYPERSPATIAL TRADE ANALYSES APPROPRIATE FOR EVALUATING MULTIATTRIBUTE TRADES IN AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS. 2. DEVELOP APPROACHES TO DEFINING UTILITY WHICH INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL AND OTHER SYSTEM PERFORMANCE PARAMETERS AND WHICH CAN FORMALLY INCORPORATE DIFFERENT VALUE STRUCTURES FROM MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS IN THE AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM. 3. EXPAND CURRENT AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM MODELS TO INCORPORATE THESE ADVANCED UTILITY AND MULTI-DIMENSIONAL ANALYSIS METHODS. 4. EVALUATE THE METHODS BY APPLYING THEM TO ONE OR MORE SAMPLE TRADE PROBLEMS WHICH INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES WITHIN THE CURRENT AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM AND HENCE REFINE THE METHODOLOGIES. 5. FURTHER EVALUATE THE METHODS BY EXPLORING MORE SIGNIFICANT TRADE PROBLEMS INCLUDING THE INCORPORATION OF NEW OPERATIONAL CAPABILITIES AND CONCEPTS INCLUDING REPRESENTATIVE ELEMENTS OF NEXTGEN. EXPECTED SIGNIFICANCE THE EXPECTED SIGNIFICANCE OF THIS RESEARCH WOULD BE PROFOUND. AT PRESENT MANY OPERATIONAL, INVESTMENT AND POLICY DECISIONS ARE BASED ON VERY SIMPLE ONE OR TWO DIMENSIONAL TRADE ANALYSIS AND DO NOT FULLY INCORPORATE IMPORTANT CONSIDERATIONS SUCH AS THE SPECTRUM OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS. THE METHODS DEVELOPED IN THE PROPOSED RESEARCH ARE EXPECTED TO ENABLE SIMULTANEOUS CONSIDERATION OF MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES WHICH WILL BE CRITICAL AS ENVIRONMENTAL CONSIDERATIONS BECOME COMPARABLE IN IMPORTANCE TO SAFETY, CAPACITY AND ECONOMICS IN NEXTGEN DEVELOPMENT.

EAPD-BIO.0002-12; E-233-2003/1-US-28; LI; PATENT LEGAL SERVICES

PROPOSAL SUMMARY CURRENT SHEETS ARE IMPORTANT SIGNATURES OF MAGNETIC RECONNECTION DURING THE ERUPTION OF CONFINED SOLAR MAGNETIC STRUCTURES. MODELS OF CORONAL MASS EJECTIONS (CMES) INVOLVE FORMATION OF A CURRENT SHEET (CS) CONNECTING THE EJECTED FLUX ROPE WITH THE POST-ERUPTION MAGNETIC LOOP ARCADE. CURRENT SHEETS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN WHITE LIGHT (WL) CORONAGRAPH IMAGES OF CMES AS NARROW RAYS TRAILING THE OUTWARD-MOVING CME CORE, AND IN UV SPECTRA AS NARROW, HIGH TEMPERATURE FEATURES. SCIENTIFIC PROBLEM AND MOTIVATION WE PROPOSE AN INVESTIGATION OF CME CSS USING IMAGING AND SPECTRAL OBSERVATIONS TO ADDRESS THESE QUESTIONS: WHAT ARE THE DYNAMICS AND PLASMA CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CSS THROUGHOUT THE CORONA? WHAT ARE THE 3-D CHARACTERISTICS OF WL CSS? ARE THESE RESULTS CONSISTENT WITH RECONNECTION CME MODELS; HOW CAN WE CONSTRAIN/REFINE THE MODELS? METHODOLOGY WE HAVE ASSEMBLED A TEAM WITH WORLD-CLASS EXPERTISE IN STUDYING CMES AND RELATED CSS USING BOTH IMAGING AND SPECTRAL DATA. THE TEAM WILL ANALYZE DATA FROM THE SOHO, STEREO, HINODE AND SDO MISSIONS. WE WILL USE AND EXTEND CATALOGS OF WL CME-RAYS (CSS), UVCS CMES AND CSS, AND OF ERUPTIVE EVENTS WITH CSS OBSERVED IN THE LOW CORONA. THE DATA WILL INCLUDE CMES AND RAYS (CSS) OBSERVED BY SOHO (LASCO, UVCS AND EIT) FROM 1996 TO THE PRESENT AND BY STEREO SECCHI, HINODE XRT AND EIS, AND SDO AIA INSTRUMENTS FROM 2007 TO THE PRESENT. WE PROPOSE A THOROUGH INVESTIGATION OF CME CSS IN A 3-PHASE STUDY: PHASE 1) COMPLETE THE SOHO STUDY BY ANALYSIS OF THE BEST LASCO-UVCS RAY EVENTS, DETERMINE THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE WL RAYS THROUGH THE OUTER CORONA USING BOTH LASCO C2 AND C3 IMAGES AND NEAR THE SURFACE USING EIT IMAGES, AND EXTEND THE WL RAY CATALOG TO THE PRESENT TO INCLUDE THE STEREO, HINODE AND SDO OBSERVATION PERIODS. PHASE 2) ANALYZE THE 3-D CHARACTERISTICS OF THE WL RAYS USING BOTH THE LASCO AND SECCHI COR CORONAGRAPH IMAGES, BASED ON A STUDY BY PATSOURAKOS AND VOURLIDAS (2011). PHASE 3) USE THE OVERLAPPING OBSERVATIONS TO STUDY THE LOW CORONA CHARACTERISTICS OF CSS WITH HINODE XRT AND EIS, SDO AIA AND SECCHI EUVI DATA, AND COMPARE THESE RESULTS WITH THE OUTER CORONA WL RAYS. EXPECTED RESULTS PRODUCE A CATALOG OF WL CME RAY EVENTS FROM THE LASCO AND SECCHI CORONAGRAPHS. EXTRACT THE 3-D CHARACTERISTICS OF WL CSS DERIVE THE PLASMA CHARACTERISTICS OF CSS IN LOW CORONA AND COMPARE WITH WL CSS IN OUTER CORONA COMPARE THE RESULTS TO ERUPTIVE FLARE/CME MODELS TO AID IN CONSTRAINING THE MODELS RELEVANCE TO NASA S HELIOPHYSICS RESEARCH OUR PROJECT GOALS DIRECTLY SUPPORT THE NASA HELIOPHYSICS FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS PROVIDED IN THE 2010 NASA SCIENCE PLAN AND ARE RELEVANT TO THE OBJECTIVE OF NASA S HELIOPHYSICS RESEARCH PROGRAM OF UNDERSTANDING THE BASIC PHYSICAL PROCESSES UNDERLYING THE SUN AND PLANETARY ENVIRONMENTS. IT DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE PROGRAM S FOCUS OF UNDERSTANDING THE ORIGIN AND NATURE OF SOLAR ACTIVITY AND ITS INTERACTION WITH EARTH AND PLANETS, THROUGH STUDYING CMES. THIS EFFORT SUPPORTS NASA'S SHP PROGRAM USING A BROAD RANGE OF NASA SPACECRAFT OBSERVATIONS OF CMES.

THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS FUNDING FOR US SCIENTISTS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE 48TH INTERNATIONAL LIEGE COLLOQUIUM ON OCEAN DYNAMICS IN LIEGE, BELGIUM, FROM MAY 23-27, 2016. THE COLLOQUIUM TOPIC IS SUBMESOSCALE PROCESSES: MECHANISMS, IMPLICATIONS, AND NEW FRONTIERS. THE COLLOQUIUM WILL PROVIDE A FORUM FOR DISCUSSION OF VARIOUS ASPECTS OF SUBMESOSCALE PROCESSES, RANGING FROM THEIR DYNAMICS, THEIR INTERACTION WITH OCEAN PHENOMENA, THEIR IMPLICATIONS FOR TRANSPORT AND ENERGY TRANSFER ACROSS SCALES, AND THEIR ROLE IN PRIMARY PRODUCTION, EXPORT AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL DISTRIBUTIONS. THE REQUESTED FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE A TRAVEL SUBSIDY OF UP TO $2,000 TO 13 US SCIENTISTS, POSTDOCS AND STUDENTS TO TRAVEL TO THE COLLOQUIUM, AND $2,500 TO COVER THE TRAVEL AND REGISTRATION COSTS OF ONE US KEYNOTE SPEAKER. THE SELECTION OF PARTICIPANTS RECEIVING THE SUBSIDY WILL BE BY THE US MEMBERS OF THE SCIENTIFIC COMMITTEE IN RESPONSE TO PARTICIPANT APPLICATIONS FOR TRAVEL SUPPORT. THE PARTICIPATION OF US SCIENTISTS IN THIS INTERNATIONAL COLLOQUIUM ON SUBMESOSCALE PROCESSES WILL FOSTER NEW COLLABORATIONS AND CROSSCUTTING THEMES FOR FUTURE RESEARCH.

doc.ContractDescription: THE DEEP OCEAN CAN ACT AS A LONG-TERM SINK FOR THE INCREASED ANTHROPOGENIC CARBON IN THE ATMOSPHERE THROUGH THE BIOLOGICAL AND SOLUBILITY PUMPS. THE BIOLOGICAL CARBON PUMP (BCP), IS THE PROCESS BY WHICH INORGANIC CARBON IS FIXED BY ORGANISMS IN THE SHALLOW OCEAN INTO ORGANIC CARBON AND THEN TRANSPORTED TO DEPTH OR REMINERALIZED TO FORM DISSOLVED ORGANIC OR INORGANIC CARBON. UNDERSTANDING THE BCP IS CENTRAL TO ELUCIDATING THE OCEANIC CONTROLS ON CLIMATE CHANGE AND DIRECTLY RELATES TO THE INVESTIGATION OF NASA'S BIG QUESTIONS FOR EARTH SCIENCES BECAUSE THE BCP PLAYS A KEY ROLE IN REGULATING CURRENT ATMOSPHERIC CARBON DIOXIDE LEVELS AND ITS EFFICIENCY WILL IMPACT HOW THE EARTH ADJUSTS TO INCREASING FOSSIL FUEL EMISSIONS IN THE FUTURE. IT HAS BEEN PREDICTED THAT WITHOUT THE BCP THE EARTH COULD SEE AN INCREASE IN ATMOSPHERIC CARBON DIOXIDE OF 200 PPMV. IN ORDER TO CONSTRAIN AND QUANTIFY THE UNDERLYING MECHANISMS OF THE BCP, AN INTEGRATION OF FIELD STUDIES OF THE CONTROLS ON BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTIVITY AND CARBON EXPORT AND THE USE OF SATELLITE-DERIVED MEASUREMENTS TO ASSESS CHANGES IN THESE PROCESSES IS NEEDED. THIS PROJECT WILL COMBINE FIELD-BASED MEASUREMENTS OF UPPER OCEAN EXPORT (TH-234), HPLC PIGMENTS, PARTICLE SIZE/DISTRIBUTION, AND SINKING-SPEED WITH SATELLITE-DERIVED MEASURES OF BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTIVITY TO INVESTIGATE THE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG THE PROCESSES CONTROLLING THE BCP. THE FIRST INVESTIGATION WILL TAKE PLACE ON THE GEOTRACES SOUTH PACIFIC CRUISE (2013) AND SUBSEQUENT STUDIES ARE PLANNED FOR BERMUDA ATLANTIC TIME SERIES AND POTENTIAL COOPEX CRUISES. TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACT OF THE BCP ON ATMOSPHERIC CARBON DIOXIDE LEVELS, COUPLED ESTIMATES ARE NEEDED OF UPPER OCEAN NET COMMUNITY PRODUCTION (NCP) AND EXPORT PRODUCTION (EP) OUT OF THE SURFACE OCEAN. THEORETICALLY, OVER LONG TIME SCALES AND LARGE SPATIAL SCALES NCP (AN INDICATOR OF HOW MUCH NET CARBON IS BEING FIXED) MUST BALANCE EP (HOW MUCH CARBON MAKES IT OUT OF THE SURFACE OCEAN) AND THEREFORE EXPORT COULD BE DETERMINED BY KNOWLEDGE OF NCP. HOWEVER, THE DECOUPLING OF NCP AND EP ON SCALES OF A FEW KILOMETERS SUGGESTS LOCAL IMBALANCES IN AUTOTROPHIC AND HETEROTROPHIC PROCESSES DUE TO THE FACT THAT NCP AND EP ARE CONTROL BY VERY DIFFERENT PROCESSES. I WILL LOOK TO RELATE REGIONAL SURFACE OCEAN EXPORT PRODUCTION TO MEASURES OF BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTIVITY AND PHYTOPLANKTON COMMUNITY STRUCTURE, AS WELL AS TO WHAT EXTENT THESE FACTORS MIGHT IMPACT THE DECOUPLING OF BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTIVITY INDICATORS AND EXPORT PRODUCTION ON SMALLER SCALES (1-10 KM) USING TH-234 METHODS (POC EXPORT), HPLC PIGMENT ANALYSIS, AND SATELLITE-DERIVED MEASUREMENTS OF CHLOROPHYLL CONCENTRATION, BACKSCATTER INTENSITY/OCEAN COLOR, SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURE, AND NET PRIMARY PRODUCTIVITY. TO DEVELOP A PREDICTIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN NCP AND EP, WE MUST INVESTIGATE THE SMALLER-SCALE VARIABILITY THAT ULTIMATELY CONTROLS THE COUPLING AND DECOUPLING OF THESE TWO PROCESSES. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY QUANTIFYING THE EXTENT TO WHICH BIOLOGICAL (PFTS) AND PHYSICAL PROPERTIES (SIZE, DENSITY, SINKING RATES) INDIVIDUALLY AND COLLECTIVELY IMPACT SURFACE OCEAN EXPORT. I WILL USE POC EXPORT, SINKING SPEED FRACTION EXPERIMENTS, PARTICLE SIZE AND DISTRIBUTION MEASUREMENTS, AND SATELLITE-DERIVED MEASUREMENTS OF PARTICLE SIZE DISTRIBUTION TO INVESTIGATE THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF BIOLOGY AND PHYSICAL PROPERTIES ON EXPORT. THE FATE OF CARBON IN SINKING CELLS, PARTICLES, AND AGGREGATES IS ULTIMATELY DETERMINED AFTER EXPORT OUT OF THE EUPHOTIC ZONE IN WHAT IS KNOWN AS THE TWILIGHT ZONE (BASE OF EUPHOTIC ZONE TO 1000 M). THIS DEPTH IS THE MOST RELEVANT BOUNDARY FOR SEQUESTRATION OF CARBON AND PROCESSES THAT CAN IMPACT ATMOSPHERIC CARBON ON CLIMATE RELEVANT TIME SCALES. I WILL ATTEMPT TO RELATE THE SUBSURFACE EFFICIENCY AND STRENGTH OF THE BCP ON REGIONAL AND LOCAL SCALES TO THE SATELLITE-DERIVED MEASUREMENTS DISCUSSED ABOVE USING 100 - 1000 M POC PROFILES AND SIZE FRACTION MEASUREMENTS.

doc.ContractDescription: A TEAM OF OCEANOGRAPHERS AND GLACIOLOGISTS PROPOSE TO LEVERAGE KEY NASA ASSETS TO VASTLY IMPROVE THE SCIENCE OF GREENLAND ICE SHEET (GRIS) MASS CHANGES. THE WORK CONSISTS OF CONNECTING OBSERVATIONS AND MODELING OF THE LARGE-SCALE CIRCULATION TO THE DETAILED PROCESSES AT THE ICE SHEET-OCEAN INTERFACE. AT THE HEART OF THE MODELING ARE THE MIT OCEAN GENERAL CIRCULATION MODEL (MITGCM), JPL&UCI'S ICE SHEET SYSTEM MODEL (ISSM), AND THE STATE ESTIMATION INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPED BY THE NASA-FUNDED "ESTIMATING THE CIRCULATION AND CLIMATE OF THE OCEAN" (ECCO) CONSORTIUM. VARIOUS SATELLITE DATA ALREADY USED IN ECCO AND ISSM, NEW DATA BECOMING AVAILABLE THROUGH NASA'S OPERATION ICEBRIDGE, TOGETHER WITH DEDICATED IN-SITU OBSERVATIONS NEAR GREENLAND WILL BE USED FOR AN IMPROVED SYNTHESIS, AND WILL BE LINKED TO DETAILED PROCESS STUDIES. THE FOLLOWING COMPONENTS ARE BEING PROPOSED: 1. LARGE-SCALE MODEL-DATA SYNTHESES OF THE ARCTIC OCEAN AND SUBPOLAR GYRE THAT ARE BEING DEVELOPED WITHIN ECCO SERVE AS A BASELINE TO ASSESS DECADAL VARIABILITY OF GREENLAND-BOUND SOURCE WATERS; EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON ASSESSING THE SKILL OF THE ESTIMATES IN TERMS OF RESIDUAL MISFITS TO SATELLITE AND IN-SITU (PRESENT AND HISTORICAL) OBSERVATIONS NEAR THE GRIS. 2. ENHANCED RESOLUTION IS REQUIRED TO RESOLVE KEY PROCESSES ON THE CONTINENTAL SHELF AND IN KEY FJORDS WHERE MAJOR GLACIERS ARE IN CONTACT WITH OCEAN WATERS; WE WILL CONDUCT AN UNPRECEDENTED 2 KM HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION CIRCUM-GREENLAND OCEAN-SEA ICE SIMULATION WHICH WILL SERVE AS BOUNDARY CONDITION FOR COUPLING THE LARGE-SCALE CIRCULATION WITH THE SHELF AND FJORD-SCALE CIRCULATION. 3. ATMOSPHERIC REANALYSIS PRODUCTS PROVIDE BEST ESTIMATES OF THE METEOROLOGY BUT LACK THE RESOLUTION AND FIDELITY THAT ARE TARGETED NEAR THE MARINE MARGIN. EXISTING PRODUCTS FROM GLOBAL AND REGIONAL PROJECTS WILL BE ANALYZED IN TERMS FIDELITY AT LOCAL SCALES. WE WILL INVESTIGATE WHETHER THE APPARENT ATMOSPHERIC VARIABILITY CAN BE RELATED TO OBSERVED FJORD-SHELF VARIABILITY, AND TO OBSERVED GLACIER FLOW SPEED AND THINNING. 4. PROCESS STUDIES ARE PROPOSED FOR TWO GLACIER/FJORD SYSTEMS IN EAST GREENLAND, 79NORTH GLACIER/FJORD AND HELHEIM GLACIER/SERMILIK FJORD, WHICH COVER A VARIETY OF RELEVANT CHARACTERISTICS (LARGE DRAINAGE BASINS; VERTICAL VERSUS SLANTED OCEAN-ICE INTERFACE; LARGE VERSUS SMALL BASAL RUNOFF). THE USE OF HYDROGRAPHIC AND, WHERE POSSIBLE, REMOTE SENSING OBSERVATIONS WILL PROVIDE A QUANTITATIVE BASIS FOR LINKING LOCAL PROCESSES TO LARGE-SCALE CIRCULATION CHANGES. 5. BASED ON CIRCUM-GREENLAND-FORCED FJORD SIMULATIONS AND MELT RATE ESTIMATES, TRANSIENT ISSM SIMULATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED TO ASSESS IMPLICATIONS FOR ICE SHEET CHANGES. SEVERAL CRITICAL ISSM IMPROVEMENTS WILL IMPLEMENTED, INCLUDING CALVING FRONT DYNAMICS. SENSITIVITY CALCULATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED IN CONJUNCTION WITH DATA COLLECED AT THE TWO PROCESS REGIONS TO ASSESS DYNAMIC THINNING AND GLACIER FRONT RETREAT IN RESPONSE TO LARGE-SCALE OCEANIC AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY. 6. THE AVAILABLE DATA, IMPROVED MODEL-DATA SYNTHESIS, AND ATMOSPHERIC FIELDS WILL BE USED IN CONJUNCTION TO TEST THE DECADAL PROGRESSION OF REGIONAL WARMING, ICE-OCEAN MELTING, AND MASS LOSS. IMPROVED ICEBRIDGE FJORD BATHYMETRY, SATELLITE AND GPS MEASUREMENTS OF THE GLACIER TERMINI, TOGETHER WITH ICE-OCEAN BOUNDARY CONDITIONS SHOULD HELP TO VASTLY IMPROVE THE SIMULATED ICE FLOW CHANGES OF OUTLET GLACIERS IN RESPONSE TO PERTURBATIONS. THE IMPACT OF ABOVE OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC PROCESSES ON GRIS WILL BE STUDIED USING THE ISSM. SENSITIVITY EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CARRIED OUT IN ORDER TO STUDY LINKAGES BETWEEN OPEN-OCEAN, FJORD CIRCULATION, ATMOSPHERIC PROCESSES, AND CHANGES ON THE ICE SHEET. THESE SENSITIVITY EXPERIMENTS WILL BE USED TO QUANTIFY WHAT NEEDS TO BE MEASURED AND WITH WHAT ACCURACY IN ORDER TO MAKE IMPROVED STATEMENTS ABOUT ONGOING AND FUTURE ICE SHEET EVOLUTION SCENARIOS.

doc.ContractDescription: THERMO FISHER SCIENTIFIC OXYGEN SENSOR FOR THERMO FISHER CO/O2 ANALYZER

CURRENT UNDERSTANDING IS THAT ATMOSPHERIC LOSS IN GIANT IMPACTS, IN PARTICULAR THE MOON FORMING IMPACT, IS MINIMAL. RECENTLY HOWEVER, NEW HIGH ANGULAR MOMENTUM MOON FORMATION MODELS HAVE BEEN PROPOSED THAT OFFER THE POTENTIAL FOR MUCH GREATER LOSS FRACTIONS IN AGREEMENT WITH THE NOBLE GAS ISOTOPE DATA. WE ARE PROPOSING A COMPREHENSIVE STUDY OF ATMOSPHERIC LOSS DURING GIANT IMPACTS EVENTS WITH HIGH ANGULAR MOMENTUM WITH THE AIM OF QUANTIFYING THE ATMOSPHERIC LOSS FRACTION IN SUCH IMPACTS. WE WILL ADDRESS THIS PROBLEM IN THREE STAGES. FIRSTLY I WILL MODEL THE PRINCIPAL MECHANISMS OF LOSS THAT ARE LIKELY TO DOMINATE IN HIGH ANGULAR MOMENTUM IMPACTS. SIMPLIFIED MODELS OF EACH OF THE LOSS MECHANISMS WILL BE USED TO PRODUCE SCALING RELATIONS FOR THE LOSS FRACTION IN EACH CASE. SECONDLY THE DETERMINATIONS OF SURFACE MOTIONS DURING HIGH ANGULAR MOMENTUM IMPACTS WILL BE REFINED AND THE EFFECTS OF A CRUST INCLUDED. FINALLY WE WILL COMBINE THESE RESULTS TO DETERMINE THE TOTAL LOSS FRACTION IN GIANT IMPACTS AND TO DEVELOP SCALING LAWS BETWEEN THE PARAMETERS OF THE COLLISION AND THE ATMOSPHERIC LOSS FRACTION FOR ANY TOTAL ANGULAR MOMENTUM. THIS WORK WILL BE PERFORMED USING NUMERICAL AND COMPUTATIONAL MODELING. THE THREE HYDRODYNAMIC CODES WE WILL USE ARE: WONDY, A ONE DIMENSIONAL LAGRANGIAN SHOCK PHYSICS CODE; STH, A MULTI DIMENSIONAL EULERIAN SHOCK PHYSICS CODE; AND GADGET, A SMOOTHED PARTICLE HYDRODYNAMIC CODE THAT HAS BEEN ADAPTED FOR MODELING PLANETARY COLLISIONS. THE CALCULATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED ON HARVARD UNIVERSITYS ODYSSEY CLUSTER. COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL GREATLY IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF ATMOSPHERIC LOSS DURING GIANT IMPACTS AND HELP EXPLAIN THE ORIGIN AND EVOLUTION OF TERRESTRIAL PLANET ATMOSPHERES. COMBINED WITH GEOCHEMICAL OBSERVATIONS, THE RESULTS OF OUR WORK WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO PROVIDE CONSTRAINTS ON THE COLLISIONAL HISTORY OF THE PROTO EARTH DURING THE GIANT IMPACT PHASE. OUR OBJECTIVES THEREFORE CORRESPOND EXTREMELY WELL WITH THE AIMS OF THE PLANETARY SCIENCE RESEARCH PROGRAM TO UNDERSTAND THE EVOLUTION OF THE INNER PLANETS ATMOSPHERES, AND THE ROLES BOMBARDMENT BY LARGE PROJECTILES PLAYED .
